Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Differential Emission Measure Determination in Three-Dimension (3D) Using Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA) Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator (PI) and his team will assess and characterize a number of key performance metrics of the Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA) instrument on the newly launched Solar Dynamics Observatory spacecraft. Addressing these technical issues is crucial for the effective interpretation and analysis of AIA data by the broader scientific community. These issues include the deconvolution of the instrument's point spread function, the identification of optically thick lines-of-sight to be excluded from future analysis, and the refinement of the relevant spectroscopic physics to allow the interpretation of AIA narrow-band images. The PI's team will then apply this new knowledge of AIA performance to the use of a technique known as differential emission measure tomography (DEMT), in order to determine the three-dimensional structure and thermal properties of the global solar corona. Comparisons between DEMT reconstructions and state-of-the-art solar wind models can improve the realism of these models and, ultimately, shed light on longstanding problems of how the Sun's corona is heated and how the solar wind is energized and accelerated.

This project will benefit the solar research community and serve important educational functions. AIA data has the possibility to dramatically extend and improve the research community's ability to reconstruct the thermodynamic configuration of global solar corona from spectroscopic measurements in extreme ultraviolet wavelengths. Also, this work will be performed at the University of Michigan, where it will support direct participation of undergraduate and graduate students in the research effort. The results of this work will be presented at scientific meetings and widely disseminated to the community through scientific publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research is focused on two main goals:

Goal 1 - Addressing instrumental and analysis issues in AIA data. Such activity is a preliminary step to any application of AIA data to specific physical problems;

Goal 2 - Implementing the DEMT analysis of AIA images.

To accomplish them we have carried out three main tasks:

Task 1 - Addressing instrumental issues in AIA data (Goal 1)

Task 2 - Improving the temperature response functions of all AIA channels for AIA data analysis (Goal 1)

Task 3 - Implementing and applying DEMT analysis to AIA data to determine the 3D thermal structure of the solar corona (Goal 2)

1 - Instrumental issues in AIA data: Co-PI Frazin has worked with a graduate student of the University of Michigan to develop the blind deconvolution algorithms required for removing the stray light from AIA images, and applied the developed software to a AIA images. It was found that a large fraction of AIA count rates in coronal holes and other dim areas are due to stray light from brighter areas of the solar disk, and their removal is critical to carry out studies of coronal holes, off disk areas and even quiet Sun areas, especially if close to active regions.

2 - Improving the temperature response functions (TRF) of AIA data required to significantly improve the atomic data and spectral line intensities of the spectral code used to calculated them: CHIANTI. PI Landi has worked on this issue, by including large amounts of new data for almost all ions in CHIANTI, and improved/expanded new data sets. This work has been ongoing throughout the entire project and led to the development and release of two new major versions of CHIANTI: version 7.1 (2013) and version 8.0 (2015). As a result of improving the data, the AIA TRFs were changed by significant factors, especially for the A094 and A131 channels, and their dependence on temperature also changed. CHIANTI is freely distributed over the internet so all data and software is accessible, and the impact of the changes in both versions of CHIANTI goes way beyond AIA only. The improved TRF functions allowed us to develop a new diagnostic technique to measure the plasma density in CME cores using the AIA A193/A171 filter ratio.

3 - The DEMT analysis was applied to AIA data. Tomographic reconstructions of the emission of the entire corona were calculated, and the local DEM (LDEM) applied everywhere in the 3D reconstruction. The resulting LDEM is bimodal, with two clear peaks that demonstrate that the solar corona is multithermal locally, and that multithermality is not a by-product of line of sight integration. Also, DEMT analysis was carried out on 2D AIA images and compared to results from other works and techniques, providing good agreement. The local multithermality in general indicates that populations of loops with different properties are ubiquitous in the solar corona; the clear presence of two distinct peaks indicates that these loops belong to two families with distinct properties.

The main outcomes of this project are

1) an improved methodology to clean AIA data from stray light, which enables the scientific use of these data for low-intensity targets such as coronal holes;

2) vastly improved TRFs, which enable the scientific use of images (e.g. temperature and DEM diagnostics, and so on)

3) The first global determination of the local plasma thermodynamic structure, free from any line of sight integration issue.
